none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Henry Garrison, June 1, 1884
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Henry Garrison, June 1, 1884
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 16 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Caledonia Texs
June 1st 84

Prof L. L. McInnis
Dear Sir
If I
should again enter the
A & M C could I enter the
same class that I was in
when I left there
I have been thinking of return-
ing this fall in company with
two friend of mine
I attended school five
months after I left the
A & M C I completed to the
seventh book in Robinson Geom
& reviewed Arthmetic Algebra

Yours Truly
Henry D Garrison

**Transcription Analysis & Refinement** Okay, here's the deal. I'm looking at this handwritten letter, trying to figure out what it says. It's addressed to "Prof L. L. McInnis" and dated "June 1st 84" - that's June 1st, 1884, in Caledonia, Texas, I think. The handwriting is cursive, and some of it is a bit messy. I need to make a solid transcription, so here's my thought process. First, I'm trying to break down each part. "Dear Sir" is the greeting. Then the body: The writer, "Henry D Garrison" or something like that, wants to know if he can re-enter the "A & M C" (that's Agricultural and Mechanical College) in the same class he was in when he left. I think he is asking this. The "A & M C" is heavily emphasized in the text. I am certain. Then, he's considering returning this fall with two of his friends. He attended school for five months after leaving A&M, and finished "the seventh book in Robinson Geom" - geometry. It sounds like he did geometry. I know Robinson's Geometry was common. I am also sure it says "Geom" at the end, not "Gram" - even though I thought of it. Also, he "reviewed Arthmetic Algebra". That's a misspelling of "Arithmetic", which is common. I am also sure I see "Arithmetic". I am making sure that the text is "Texs", not "Tex". The s at the end is a squiggle, but it looks like an s. The 1st is in superscript: "1st". The layout is important. I am trying to keep the paragraphs as I see them. The line "If I" appears above the words "should again enter". I'm making sure to capture that nuance. The "If I" is a bit indented. I am sure. The word "enter" in one of the lines is messy. A difficult word is in the line "A & M C could I enter". The word "enter" is scribbled and looks like "rule g" or "take" or something else. I will stick with "enter", though I am considering "reenter". The intent is clearer, given it parallels the previous line. The closing is "Yours Truly", but the "Yours" is really faint. You can barely see it. I have the name as "Henry D Garrison". Let's summarize it. Here is the text.

Caledonia Texs
June 1st 84

Prof L. L. McInnis
Dear Sir

If I
should again enter the
A & M C could I enter the
same class that I was in
when I left there
I have been thinking of return-
ing this fall in company with
two friend of mine
I attended school five
months after I left the
A & M C I completed to the
seventh book in Robinson Geom
& reviewed Arthmetic Algebra

Yours Truly
Henry D Garrison
